title-group.article-title: Nusselt number correlations for laminar convection in three-dimensional air-filled cavities

abstract.p: This article deals with laminar natural convection in three-dimensional air-filled enclosures. The cavities under investigation have two opposite isothermal vertical walls and four adiabatic walls. The vertical and horizontal aspect ratios are in the range 5–80 and 0.2–5, respectively. The Rayleigh numbers vary between 103 and 105. These values match cavities typically found in vertical hollow alveolar bricks. The effects of the geometry and the Rayleigh number on the convection are discussed. Comparisons between purely two-dimensional cases and the results obtained in 3D are presented and analyzed. Nusselt number correlations as a function of the two aspect ratios and Rayleigh number are proposed, offering an efficient tool for thermal engineers and scientists to evaluate convection heat transfer in real three-dimensional enclosures, which are common systems in building construction.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Since the 1950s, laminar natural convection in differentially heated cavities has been widely studied in literature (Bejan, 1995; Eckert and Carlson, 1961; ElSherbiny et al., 1982; Ganguli et al., 2009; Jakob, 1949; Yin et al., 1978). In addition to its scientific interest, this problem has many industrial applications, from the cooling of electronic components to the airflow in building rooms. However, the computations have been mainly conducted in two dimensions. The number of studies dealing with convection in 3D cavities remains low, due to the high computational resource requirements for the numerical resolution of convection equations. A few studies address this problem in specific cases, such as differentially heated cubic cavities. These studies have been investigated numerically and experimentally for Rayleigh numbers ranging from 103 to 107 (Tric et al., 2000; Fusegi et al., 1991; Wakashima and Saitoh, 2004). Tric et al. (2000) discussed the flow structure using the maxima of the velocity field according to the Rayleigh number. Wakashima and Saitoh (2004) have provided the temperature and velocity profiles in several planes of the cubic cavity. Gustavsen and Thue (2007) have studied natural convection in 3D parallelepiped cavities with high vertical and low horizontal aspect ratios. Betts and Bokhari (2000) have experimentally investigated the natural convection of air in a tall differentially heated air-filled enclosure.

In two dimensions, the convection heat transfer can be characterized by three dimensionless numbers that are the Nusselt number (Nu), the Rayleigh number (Ra), and the height-to-length aspect ratio (A). Several correlations have been proposed based on numerical and experimental results, which are valid over specific ranges of Ra and A. To our knowledge, only Gustavsen and Thue (2007) attempted to propose a correlation for laminar free convection in 3D differentially heated enclosures in specific cases. At each horizontal aspect ratio, they proposed a correlation between the Nusselt number of the cavity and the Rayleigh number. They found that a single equation correlating all the parameters would not be accurate enough.

The objective of this article is to establish, for the first time, correlations between the dimensionless parameters characterizing the laminar convection in 3D differentially heated enclosures. The work has been motivated by the integration of these correlations in a 3D analytical model to compute heat transfer in vertical hollow bricks. The method we propose to build correlations can be extended to other applications dealing with 3D enclosures, with other ranges of parameters (Rayleigh numbers, aspect ratios).

sec.p: The equations described above have been solved using CASTEM,1 a program developed by the Mechanics and Technology Department (DMT) of the French Atomic Energy Commission (CEA) for the analysis of structures by the finite element method and computational fluids dynamics. The convection and diffusion terms in Navier–Stokes and heat equations are discretized by the second-order upwind streamline-upwind Petrov–Galerkin (SUPG) scheme, and time is discretized by the one-order Euler scheme (Hughes et al., 1986).
For each time step, convergence criteria for sum of normalized residues have been set to 1 × 10−4 for the continuity, momentum, and energy equations. Convergence has been ensured at every time step.
We resolve the discretized dimensionless equations (Equations (1)–(3)) for Rayleigh numbers of 103, 104, and 105 and for aspect ratios varying between 5 ≤ AZ ≤ 80 and 0.2 ≤ AY ≤ 5.

sec.title: Grid sensitivity analysis
sec.p: A grid sensitivity analysis has been performed for the lowest value of AZ (AZ = 5), the highest value of RaL (RaL = 105) and AY = 1. Five grids have been tested: two uniform grids 10 × 10 × 50 (Grid 1) and 20 × 20 × 100 (Grid 2) and three nonuniform grids 26 × 26 × 100 (Grid 3), 38 × 38 × 100 (Grid 4), and 38 × 38 × 200 (Grid 5). The nonuniform grids have a strong concentration of their nodes near the walls. The comparison between the Nusselt numbers calculated from Grid 1 and Grid 2 shows a 2.2% relative deviation. Deviations between Grids 2 and 3, Grids 3 and 4, and Grids 4 and 5 are 9.5%, 0.9%, and 0.0003%, respectively. Finally, Grid 4 has been selected for the study.

sec.title: Comparison between Nu3D and Nu2D
sec.p: Table 1 also shows the Nusselt numbers Nu2D calculated from 2D correlations proposed by ElSherbiny et al. (1982) and Zhao et al. (1997), for the same RaL and AZ as the 3D differentially heated enclosures with AY = 1. The discrepancies between Nu2D and Nu3D reach up to 37%. Therefore, applying 2D correlations to 3D enclosures is clearly not valid. The 3D correlations become necessary to model heat transfer in real cases, and this is the objective of this study.

Some accurate analyses of 3D convection heat transfer in specific cases (mostly cubic enclosures) are now available in literature, yet few correlations have been proposed and none of them take into account both vertical and horizontal aspect ratios.

sec.title: Parametric study
sec.p: We computed a design of experiments in order to determine the most influencing parameters among AY, AZ, and RaL on Nu3D. A presentation of the method can be found in study by Goupy (1988). A two-level factorial experimental design assigns the level (−1) to the lowest value of the parameters and the level (+1) to their highest value and brings out the interactions between these factors. The parameters AY, AZ, and RaL range from 0.2 to 5, from 1 to 30, and from 103 to 105, respectively (cf. Table 2). We define the effect of each parameter as the mean impact of the factor level variation on the response (here, the response is Nu3D).

caption.p: Factorial plan for the design of experiments

sec.p: Table 2 reports the effects of the parameters AY, AZ, and RaL. This shows that the most influencing parameter on Nu3D is RaL, followed by AZ and AY, in decreasing order. AY has the weakest impact on Nu3D, but it does not mean that AY can be ignored as a correlation parameter for Nu3D.

sec.title: Impact of AY on Nu3D
sec.p: Figure 2(a) gives the values of Nu3D as a function of AY for a cavity with fixed height AZ = 30. The impact of the third dimension is clear: when AY is high (more than 5), Nu3D is close to Nu2D, as the system is similar to a 2D cavity where the sides’ effects do not play a significant role. Yet, the less AY, the less Nu3D. This result confirms the previous studies such as the one of ElSherbiny et al. (1982) who experimentally showed that successively doubling AY ends in small increases of Nu3D, emphasizing the progressively weaker effect of the horizontal aspect ratio on the 3D heat transfer. Tric et al. (2000), Fusegi et al. (1991), and Wakashima and Saitoh (2004) compared 2D square enclosures with 3D cubical enclosures, all showing that Nu3D was lower than Nu2D.

caption.p: Impact of AZ and AY on Nu3D as a function of RaL; (a) Nu3D as a function of horizontal aspect ratios AY for AZ = 30; (b) Nu3D as a function of vertical aspect ratios AZ for AY = 1.

sec.title: Impact of AZ on Nu3D
sec.p: The increase of the cavity height, that is, the aspect ratio AZ, for a given Rayleigh number and a given basis (i.e., a constant AY) leads to a decrease of the Nusselt number, which tends to 1 (cf. Figure 2(b)). This is an expected result that has already been shown in 2D. Yin et al. (1978) have showed that for a given Rayleigh number, the increase of the vertical aspect ratio induces the transition from convection regime to conduction regime. This trend is also highlighted in Figure 3 that plots the horizontal temperature profiles on the segment defined by the points (0, Y = AY/2, Z = AZ/2) and (1, Y = AY/2, Z = AZ/2) for RaL = 104, for AY = 1, and for three aspect ratios AZ = 5, 10, and 30. For AZ = 5, the temperature profile is characteristic of the presence of the convection regime. Heat transfer occurs by conduction as the aspect ratio AZ gets larger; for AZ = 30, the temperature profile is almost linear (Nu3D close to 1).

caption.p: Horizontal temperature profiles in the midplane of the 3D cavity as a function of different vertical aspect ratios AZ, for RaL = 104 and AY = 0.5.

sec.title: Correlations Nu3D as a function of Nu2D and AY
sec.p: The 3D correlations have been built from 2D correlations, themselves integrating Rayleigh numbers RaL and vertical aspect ratio Az. In order to take into account for the first time the specificity of the third dimension on the Nusselt number, the parameter AY has been added. The correlation coefficients for the correlation (5a) and (5b) are 97.6% and 99.6%, respectively, showing a good agreement between the numerical results and those obtained by the correlations.
This method can be a useful tool for thermal engineers in estimating the convection heat transfer in real 3D systems.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Natural convection in 3D enclosures with vertical AZ and horizontal AY aspect ratios ranging from 5 to 80 and 0.2 to 5, respectively (for instance, cavities in vertical hollow alveolar bricks), has been modeled. Nusselt numbers have been computed for Rayleigh numbers ranging from 103 to 105. The results show that the width of the cavity has a sizeable influence on the phenomenon of 3D heat transfer: Nusselt numbers are always smaller than Nusselt numbers in 2D enclosures. Nusselt number correlations are presented for the ranges quoted, for the first time as a function of both aspect ratios. Other correlations can be built using this method provided the 2D correlations used are valid for the ranges considered.
